channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Judge temporarily blocks Trump administration's shutdown layoffs
item.description: A federal judge in San Francisco has temporarily halted the Trump administration from laying off federal workers during the shutdown, concluding that the administration likely acted illegally.
item.content:encoded: A federal judge in San Francisco has temporarily halted the Trump administration from laying off federal workers during the shutdown, concluding that the administration likely acted illegally.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hsu

item.title: Democratic Sen. Chris Coons of Delaware talks about the ongoing government shutdown
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Sen. Chris Coons, D- Del., about the ongoing government shutdown and what he's hearing from federal workers in his state.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Sen. Chris Coons, D- Del., about the ongoing government shutdown and what he's hearing from federal workers in his state.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: Weeks after winning election, Arizona congresswoman is still waiting to be sworn in
item.description: Speaker Mike Johnson says he can't swear in Arizona Congresswoman-elect Adelita Grijalva because of the shutdown, but critics say he's trying to avoid a vote on releasing the Epstein files.
item.content:encoded: Speaker Mike Johnson says he can't swear in Arizona Congresswoman-elect Adelita Grijalva because of the shutdown, but critics say he's trying to avoid a vote on releasing the Epstein files.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Grisales

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: President Trump appeared to confirm reports of CIA operations in Venezuela, a judge blocks the shutdown layoffs, the military was paid despite the shutdown, but uncertainty remains
item.content:encoded: President Trump appeared to confirm reports of CIA operations in Venezuela, a judge blocks the shutdown layoffs, the military was paid despite the shutdown, but uncertainty remains
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: Fans and scholars flock to New Jersey for 'Born to Run' 50th anniversary symposium
item.description: Dozens of fans and scholars came from as far away as France for a New Jersey symposium celebrating the 50th anniversary of Bruce Springsteen's landmark album "Born to Run."
item.content:encoded: Dozens of fans and scholars came from as far away as France for a New Jersey symposium celebrating the 50th anniversary of Bruce Springsteen's landmark album "Born to Run."
item.dc:creator: Frank Langfitt

item.title: Green sea turtles no longer endangered as global population rebounds
item.description: Once endangered, the global green sea turtle population is rebounding, according to a new report from the International Union for Conservation of Nature.
item.content:encoded: Once endangered, the global green sea turtle population is rebounding, according to a new report from the International Union for Conservation of Nature.
item.dc:creator: Hosts

item.title: Affordable housing takes center stage in New York City mayoral race
item.description: The rising cost of housing has driven some New York City residents to leave the Big Apple. For those who remain, affordable housing has become a top issue in the race for mayor.
item.content:encoded: The rising cost of housing has driven some New York City residents to leave the Big Apple. For those who remain, affordable housing has become a top issue in the race for mayor.
item.dc:creator: David Brand

item.title: Is there a link between online gaming communities and violence? An expert weighs in
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Cynthia Miller-Idriss, director of the Polarization and Extremism Research and Innovation Lab, about links between online gaming communities and violence.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Cynthia Miller-Idriss, director of the Polarization and Extremism Research and Innovation Lab, about links between online gaming communities and violence.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: President Trump talks of striking Venezuela
item.description: President Trump appeared to confirm reports that he approved covert CIA operations inside Venezuela.
item.content:encoded: President Trump appeared to confirm reports that he approved covert CIA operations inside Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: Health insurance premiums are going up next year — unless you work at these companies
item.description: As U.S. health insurance costs rise, some companies are paying for all of their workers' premiums. It's a big expense — but they say it pays off.
item.content:encoded:
As U.S. health insurance costs rise, some companies are paying for all of their workers' premiums. It's a big expense — but they say it pays off.

(Image credit: Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Maria Aspan
